=<font color="#003366">Reference Manual</font>=
A reference manual is a place, where the developer describes his creation in details. It is often a very dry and concrete document, reading which can be quite boring. You can check out the [http://www.lua.org/manual/5.1/manual.html Lua documentation] for an example of a typical reference manual.<br>
In this manual I'll try to keep a balance between technicality and lucidity of the content.
==<font color="#006666">Detailed Description of Objects</font>==
Objects are basically what RAICK is made of. About 80% of what the framework offers is in one way or another related to them. They are divided into 2 categories:
 * Single objects
 Exist only in a single exemplar, which is automatically created upon startup of your script.
 * Multipliable objects
 Can be created an arbitrary number of times using the _constructor_, which is located in a global variable with the same name as the type of the object(for example, constructor for object `Cell` is located in the global variable `Cell`). The constructor is nothing more than a function and like every function it can take arguments(for example, `Cell(20,30)` creates a `Cell` object with coordinates (20,30)).<br>
Some objects allow operators to be used on them(you can distinguish them by the <u>*Operators*</u> subsection). For example, you may remember that we have used operator `..` to get the distance between your homunculus and its target in the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/GettingStarted#Back_to_Our_Activities Getting Started] guide.<br>
You may also notice that the <u>*Constructors*</u> subsection is in plural. That is because objects can indeed have multiple constructors. Every constructor takes a different number/types of arguments and based on that produces an object with desired properties. A good example is the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Logger Logger] object.<br>
The <u>*_is_ Methods*</u> subsection is used to describe what types and values does the _is_ group of methods understand for the current object. They are used to gain yes/no answers about the object. The group consists of 2 methods: `is` and `isNot`, which in turn have 2 forms, making a total of 4 methods. They can be described as follows:
  * First form of `is` method:
  `object.is(value1, value2, value3, ...)`
  * Second form of `is` method:
  `object.is.value`
  * First form of `isNot` method:
  `object.isNot(value1, value2, value3, ...)`
  * Second form of `isNot` method:
  `object.isNot.value`
The first form of the `is` method can receive an arbitrary number of arguments of any type, but only certain values have meaning for it. The method returns `true` if at least one of the given values(as if all arguments were grouped  with `or`) is "telling" the truth about the current object. If all given values are either "lying" or are unknown to the method it will return `false`. The second form does the same, but can take only one `string` argument, which is passed to the method in a very original and convenient way. For example, `actor.is.visible` is just another way of writing `actor.is("visible")`. Although the second form is more restricted it is nonetheless faster to write and far easier to read and that's why i decided to introduce it.<br>
The `isNot` method is the opposite of `is`. It returns `true` if all given values are "lying" about the current object or are unknown to the method and `false`, if at least one of the value is "telling" the truth.
<br>
Last thing worth mentioning is that all string argument are case insensitive meaning that, for example, `actor.is("VISiBLe")` or `actor.is.ViSiBle` would also be accepted. Furthermore, they are delimiter insensitive, which means that `actor.is("a bad person")`, `actor.is("a_badPERSON")` or `actor.is.AbadPerson` would refer to the same thing.<br><br>
Objects that are direct representations of the in-game objects of Ragnarok(actors, cell, your homunculus/mercenary, your character) have 2 special tables inside each of them. One is called `prev`, the other `last`. The first one is used to store information about the object from the previous call of the AI by the client(remember that the data changes only between those calls). The information in the second table changes only when the current data is changed. For example:
  * The script has started and the AI is called for the first time. The current cell of your character is (15,23). The previous cell is `nil` and the last cell is also `nil` since there is no previous data available.
  * The second call. Your character does not move. The current cell is (15,23). The previous cell is now also (15,23), since this is the value of the previous call, but the last cell remains `nil`, because the was no change in the value.
  * The third call. Your character has moved. The current cell is now (16,24). The previous cell remains (15,23), but the last cell changes to (15,23), since the current value has changed and we now know that the last cell, on which our character has stepped was (15,23).
===<font color="#006600">A Few Words About the Syntax</font>===
In the description below i use some syntactical aids to reduce the amount of unnecessary repeating text and make the manual more compact.<br>
For constructors, operators and object methods:
  * I use *<font color="#0052A3">blue</font>*.
  * After the :: i specify the return type or value of the constructor/method/operator. If the constructor/method/operator can return different types in different situations(for example, `nil` if something is wrong), then those types are separated with | .
For arguments and object fields:
  * I use *<font color="#5E5B00">dark yellow</font>* for optional arguments(the ones that you can omit when calling a function/method/constructor) and *<font color="#006666">cyan</font>* for mandatory arguments and object fields.
  * If the argument is optional, then i specify the default value(which is used if the argument is omitted) after the | .
  * After the :: i specify the type of the argument/field. If the argument/field can have/contain different types, then those types are separated with | . If the argument is supposed to have not only a certain type, but also i certain value(for example, > 0), then the restriction is specified inside ( ) next to the type.
For strings with specific format:
  * I specify the variable part like so: `[partOfTheString]`. For example: `"abc[num]"`, where `[num]` is a number, would mean that i refer to strings with `abc` in the beginning and numbers after that, such as: `"abc123"`, `"abc9"` or `"abc0"`.
I also use self-made pseudo-types to more specifically identify some return values or arguments:
  * `range` - to specify that the function can take an arbitrary number of arguments or return an arbitrary number of values.
  * `any` - to specify that the value can be of any type.
  * `self` - to specify that the method returns the reference to the same object it has been called from. For example,  `list.add(2).add(5).remove(1)` would add `2` and `5` to the list and then remove the 1'st elements from it leaving just 1 element `5`.
<br>
----
===<font color="#006600">Multipliable Objects</font>===
====<font color="#660000">Value</font>====
The most primitive object in RAICK. It is used mainly to store the data about [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Actor actors]. Each object consists of a `number` and a `string`. In most cases the string is used to describe or translate the meaning of the number(ID), but you can also use the number, for example, to index the string or use only the string without the number. What i am saying is that it is just a `string`-`number` pair and it can be interpreted in many ways according to the place or situation it is used in.<br>
Later in this guide i will specify `Value` objects in the following manner: `"string" (number1, number2, ...)`. For example:
    * `"Assassin" (12)` specifies a `Value` object with `"Assassin"` for a name and 12 for the number(ID).
    * `"Attacking" (2, 9)` specifies 2 `Value` objects, both having `"Attacking"` for a name and 2, 9 for the ID respectively.
In these examples i have specified `Value` objects that translate original ID's of a character type and an action/motion type into human-readable strings and that is actually the main idea behind this object.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Value( <font color="#006666">name</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">id</font> )</font>* :: `Value`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*name*</font> :: `string`<br>
        Some name.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*id*</font> | `0` :: `number`<br>
        Some number, ID or index.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a new `Value` object with given <font color="#006666">*name*</font> and <font color="#006666">*value*</font>.
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*name*</font> :: `string`<br>
      The name of the value.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*id*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The ID of the value.<br>
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted Types*<br><br>
         * `Value`
         Returns `true` if the given value is the same as the current.
         * `number`
         Returns `true` if the given number equals the <font color="#006666">*id*</font> of the current object.
         * `string`
         Returns `true` if the given string equals the <font color="#006666">*name*</font> of the current object.
      * *Accepted `string` Values* (They are checked if the given string does not equal <font color="#006666">*name*</font>)<br><br>
         * `"evolved[HomType]"`
         Returns `true` if the current object is describing an evolved homunculus of type  `[HomType]`. For example: `"evolvedFilir"`, `"evolvedVanilmirth"`.
         * `"[HomType]Evolved"`
         The same as the previous one, but here `evolved` is written after the type. For example: `"lifEvolved"`, `"amistrEvolved"`.
         * `"[ScrollLvl][MercType]"`
         Returns `true` if the current object is describing a mercenary of type `[MercType]`, which is summoned from scroll of lvl `[ScrollLvl]`. For example: `"6Bowman"`, `"1fencer"`.
         * `"[MercType][ScrollLvl]"`
         The same as the previous one, except the lvl of the scroll is now in the back. For example: `"Lancer10"`, `"bowman3"`.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Cell</font>====
Represents a cell with (x,y) coordinates on the current map/location. The coordinates of a cell, which your character is currently occupying can always be checked using the */where* command.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Cell( <font color="#006666">x</font> , <font color="#006666">y</font> )</font>* :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*x*</font> :: `number` ( > 0 )<br>
        The X-coordinate of the cell.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*y*</font> :: `number` ( > 0 )<br>
        The Y-coordinate of the cell.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a `Cell` object with (<font color="#006666">*x*</font>, <font color="#006666">*y*</font>) coordinates.
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*x*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The X-coordinate of the cell.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*y*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The Y-coordinate of the cell.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*occupier*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` | `Homunculus` | `Mercenary` | `nil`<br>
      The "live" object, which is currently standing on the cell. Contains `nil` if the cell is empty. In case on multiple occupiers contains only one of them.<br>
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted Types*<br><br>
         * `Cell`
         Returns `true` if the given cell is the same as the current.
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"visible"`
         Returns `true` if the current cell is in range of sight of your character.
         * `"occupied"`
         Returns `true` if the current cell is occupied by some actor.
         * `"[x];[y]"`
         Returns `true` if the current cell has specified (`[x]`,`[y]`) coordinates. The delimiter ; can be replaced with anything you want as long as it is not a number.  For example `"23;45"`, `"23|45"`.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
  * <u>*Operators*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3"><font color="#006666">cell</font> + <font color="#006666">vector</font> `*` <font color="#5E5B00">distance</font></font>* :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br>
        An arbitrary `Cell` object.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br>
        An arbitrary `Vector` object.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*distance*</font> | `1` :: `number`<br>
        The distance, by which the *<font color="#006666">cell</font>* will be shifted in the direction of *<font color="#006666">vector</font>*. Negative values will shift it in the opposite direction.<br>
      * *Description*
        This equation returns the cell, which is *<font color="#5E5B00">distance</font>* cells away from the *<font color="#006666">cell</font>* in the direction defined by *<font color="#006666">vector</font>*.
    * *<font color="#0052A3"><font color="#006666">cell</font> .. <font color="#006666">object</font></font>* :: `number` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br>
        An arbitrary `Cell` object.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*object*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        Any in-game object, distance till which you want to know.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the distance(in cells) between <font color="#006666">*cell*</font> and <font color="#006666">*object*</font> or `nil` if <font color="#006666">*object*</font> is an actor, which is not visible.
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Actor</font>====
Represents an in-game character(monster, NPC or player character), which can be distinguished by it's unique ID. `Owner`, `Homunculus` and `Mercenary` objects can also be called actors, but they are allocated into separate objects, since they are _special_ actors(you can get more data about them and send commands to some of them).
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Actor( <font color="#5E5B00">id</font> )</font>* :: `Actor`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*id*</font> | `0` :: `number` ( >= 0 )<br>
        ID of the actor.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns an `Actor` object, which represent an in-game character with given ID.
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*id*</font> :: `number`<br>
      Actor's ID.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*status*</font> :: `Value`<br>
      Actor's current visibility status. Can be one of the following:<br><br>
        * `"Unknown" (0)`
        The actor is outside of the vision range and the AI cannot get any data about it.
        * `"Hidden" (1)`
        The actor is inside the vision range, but it is visually hidden(_Hiding_, _Clocking_ etc), which means that the AI cannot get it's location.
        * `"Visible" (2)`
        The actor is visually observable.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.status*</font> :: `Value`<br>
      Actor's previous visibility status.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.status*</font> :: `Value`<br>
      Actor's last visibility status.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br>
      Actor's current cell.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br>
      Actor's previous cell.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br>
      Actor's last cell.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*action*</font> :: `Value`<br>
      Actor's current action. Can be one of the following:<br><br>
        * `"Unknown" (-1)`
        The action is unknown to RAICK.
        * `"Standing" (0)`
        The actor is standing.
        * `"Moving" (1)`
        The actor is moving.
        * `"Attacking" (2, 9)`
        The actor is attacking.
        * `"Dead" (3)`
        The actor is dead.
        * `"Damaged" (4)`
        The actor is being damaged.
        * `"Bending" (5)`
        The actor is bending to place something on the ground or to pick something up.
        * `"Sitting" (6)`
        The actor is sitting.
        * `"Casted" (7, 20, 21, 22, 23, 24, 26, 30, 31, 32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 38, 39, 40)`
        The actor has casted/used a skill.
        * `"Casting" (8, 13, 18, 19, 28, 37, 41, 42)`
        The actor is casting a skill.
        * `"Throwing" (12)`
        The actor is throwing something.
        * `"Dancing" (16)`
        The actor is dancing.
        * `"Performing" (17)`
        The actor is performing a song.
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.action*</font> :: `Value`<br>
      Actor's previous action.
      * <font color="#006666">*last.action*</font> :: `Value`<br>
      Actor's last action.
      * <font color="#006666">*target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
      Actor's current target. Contains a blank actor(ID = 0) if the current actor has no targets. The target is set when you have visually observed that the actor has attacked someone or has started casting any kind of targeted skill. The target is preserved until changed and is reseted(turned to blank actor), when the actor goes beyond your vision range.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
      Actor's previous target.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
      Actor's last target.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*group*</font> :: `Value`<br>
      _Note: This field is not defined in the mercenary script, since they cannot distinguish types._<br><br>
      Actor's type group. Can be one of the following:<br><br>
        * `"Unknown" (0)`
        The group is unknown to RAICK.
        * `"Player" (1)`
        The actor is a player.
        * `"Mob" (2)`
        The actor is a monster.
        * `"NPC" (3)`
        The actor is an NPC.
        * `"Homunculus" (4)`
        The actor is a homunculus.
        * `"Mercenary" (5)`
        The actor is a mercenary.
        * `"WoE Stone" (6)`
        The actor is an emperium or any defense stone/barricade in WoE 2.0.
        * `"WoE Guardian" (7)`
        The actor is a guardian in the castle(not the one in the _Thor's Volcano_).
      * <font color="#006666">*type*</font> :: `Value`
      _Note: This field is not defined in the mercenary script, since they cannot distinguish types._<br><br>
      Actor's type. Can be one of the following depending of the <font color="#006666">*group*</font>:<br><br>
        * `"Unknown" (-1)`
        The type is unknown to RAICK.
        * For <font color="#006666">*group*</font> `"Player"`:<br><br>

      * <font color="#006666">*vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br>
      Actor's current motion vector. This vector reflects the current movement direction of the actor. More about vectors [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Vector here].<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br>
      Actor's previous motion vector.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br>
      Actor's last motion vector.<br>
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted Types*<br><br>
         * `Actor`
         Returns `true` if the given actor is the same as the current.
         * `number`
         Returns `true` if the current actor has the same ID.
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"[id]"`
         Returns `true` if the current actor's ID equals `[id]`.
         * `"player"`
         Returns `true` if the current actor is a player character.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
  * <u>*Operators*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3"><font color="#006666">actor</font> .. <font color="#006666">object</font></font>* :: `number` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*actor*</font> :: `Actor`<br>
        An arbitrary `Actor` object.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*object*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        Any in-game object, distance till which you want to know.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the distance(in cells) between <font color="#006666">*actor*</font> and <font color="#006666">*object*</font> or `nil` if at least one of them is not visible.
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Points</font>====
Represents your or your bot's HP or SP. It is very similar to the `Value` object, but has some extra fields and `is` method functionality allowing you to easily get all the information you need about those values.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Points( <font color="#006666">current</font> , <font color="#006666">max</font> )</font>* :: `Points`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*current*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The current value of HP or SP(depending on what the object represents).<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*max*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The maximum value of HP or SP.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a new `Points` object with given current and maximum values. This objects will represent the state of the HP or SP in the given moment of time. Normally, you would not need to create any of these objects yourself, but the constructor is still available incase you can think of a way to use this object for your own purposes.
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*current*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The current value of HP or SP.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*max*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The maximum value of HP or SP.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*percent*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The current percent value of HP or SP.<br>
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted Types*<br><br>
         * `Points`
         Returns `true` if the given object has the same <font color="#006666">*current*</font> and <font color="#006666">*max*</font> field values as the current one.
         * `number`
         Returns `true` if the given number equals the <font color="#006666">*current*</font> field value of the current object.
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"full"`
         Returns `true` if current object's <font color="#006666">*current*</font> value equals <font color="#006666">*max*</font>.
         * `"[Operator][Current]"`
         Returns `true` if current object's <font color="#006666">*current*</font> value fits the condition given inside the string. The `[Current]` is the value of the <font color="#006666">*current*</font> field and the `[Operator]` can be: `=`, `==`, `>`, `<`, `>=`, `<=` or not specified at all(which is the same as `=`, `==`). The meaning is straightforward, for example: `"1456"`, `"= 1456"` or `"==1456"` would all mean _current value equals 1456_ and `">1378"` would mean _current value is larger, than 1378_. You can also put spaces between the operator and the value as shown above with `"= 1456"`.
         * `"[Operator][Percent]%"`
         The same as previous one, but checks the <font color="#006666">*percent*</font> field. For example: `"56.7%"`, `"< 100%"`, `">=10.134323%"`.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Skill</font>====
Represents the skills that your bot can use. It is used either to get information about the skill or to order your bot to use it. Although this skills has a constructor you would not normally need to use it, because every skill object available can be accessed by it's name. For example if you query variables: `Devotion`, `TouchOfHeal`, `SBR44`, `MentalChange` they would all contain skill objects for those skills. RAICK even knows the synonyms and some shorter versions used by players: `Sacrifice`, `HealingHands`, `SBR`, `Mental`.
<br>
All names are case and delimiter insensitive, which means that your can write `S_B_R` or `healing_HAND_S` and you would still get your objects.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Skill( <font color="#006666">id</font> )</font>* :: `Skill` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*id*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The ID of the skill.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the `Skills` object representing the skill with the given ID or `nil` if no such skill exist.
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*id*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The ID of the skill.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*name*</font> :: `string`<br>
      The name of the skill.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*maxLevel*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The maximum level of the skill.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*range*</font> :: `number` | `nil`<br>
      The range of the skill. Contains the maximum distance from the owner for skill to be usable incase of homunculus supportive skills like _Urgent Escape_. `nil` if the skill does not have any range restrictions.<br>
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">sp( <font color="#5E5B00">lvl</font> )</font>* :: `number`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*lvl*</font> | <font color="#006666">*maxLevel*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The level of the skill.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the amount SP needed to use the current skill of specified level.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">duration( <font color="#5E5B00">lvl</font> )</font>* :: `number`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*lvl*</font> | <font color="#006666">*maxLevel*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The level of the skill.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the duration of effect in milliseconds for the current skill of specified level. Returns 0 if the skill does not have a duration.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">delay( <font color="#5E5B00">lvl</font> )</font>* :: `number`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*lvl*</font> | <font color="#006666">*maxLevel*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The level of the skill.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the fixed delay in milliseconds(for example, after supportive skills like _Urgent Escape_) for the current skill of specified level. Returns 0 if the skill does not have a fixed delay.
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">List</font>====
A simple list for storing multiple values and manipulating them.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">List( <font color="#5E5B00">…</font> )</font>* :: `List`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*…*</font> :: `range`<br>
        A range of values of any type.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a new `List` object containing the specified values or an empty list if no values are given.
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*size*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The number of elements in the list.<br>
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">clear()</font>* :: `self`<br>
    Clears the list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">clone()</font>* :: `List`<br>
    Returns a copy of the list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">each()</font>* :: `function`<br>
    Returns an _iteration function_ for the current list. All you need to know about this function is that it used to go through the list using the `for` loop like so:
    <code language="lua">
for index, value in list.each() do
end
</code>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">elements()</font>* :: `range`<br>
    Returns the content of the list as a range of elements(as if the values were written one after another with commas between them).
    * *<font color="#0052A3">get( <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `any` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> | <font color="#006666">*size*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The number of the element.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font>'th element of the list or the last one if <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> is omitted or `nil` if the list is empty.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">add( <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that needs to be added.<br>
      * *Description*
        Adds the given value to the list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">addList( <font color="#006666">l</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*l*</font> :: `List`<br>
        The list of values that need to be added.<br>
      * *Description*
        Adds all elements of the given list to the current list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">mergeList( <font color="#006666">l</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*l*</font> :: `List`<br>
        The list of values that need to be merged with the current one.<br>
      * *Description*
        Adds only those elements of <font color="#006666">*l*</font> that don't exist in the current list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">remove( <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> | <font color="#006666">*size*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The number of the element.<br>
      * *Description*
        Removes the <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font>'th element from the list or the last one if <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> is omitted or does nothing if the list is empty.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">removeList( <font color="#006666">l</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*l*</font> :: `List`<br>
        The list of values that need to be removes from the current list.<br>
      * *Description*
        Removes all elements from the current list that exist in <font color="#006666">*l*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">removeAll( <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that needs to be removed from the list.<br>
      * *Description*
        Removes all encounters(if there are many identical values) of <font color="#006666">*v*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">contains( <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        An arbitrary value.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns `true` if the current list contains the given value.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">containsList( <font color="#006666">l</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*l*</font> :: `List`<br>
        An arbitrary list.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns `true` if the current list contains all values of the given list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">closestTo( <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        A location or an in-game character.<br>
      * *Description*
        Looks through all objects of the current list, between which the distance can be calculated and returns the closest object to <font color="#006666">*v*</font> or `nil` if the list does not contain any objects of that kind.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">farthestFrom( <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        A location or an in-game character.<br>
      * *Description*
        Looks through all objects of the current list, between which the distance can be calculated and returns the farthest object from <font color="#006666">*v*</font> or `nil` if the list does not contain any objects of that kind.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">expand()</font>* :: `self`
    After calling this method following methods appear in the list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">filter( <font color="#006666">f</font> )</font>* :: `List`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*f*</font> :: `function`<br>
        The filtering function.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a new list containing only the values approved by the given filter. Allows filtering out certain data without the use of loops. The filtering function receives one argument and must return `true` if the value is approved and `false` otherwise. For example:
        <code language="lua">
list = List(1,2,3)
  
function    filter(value)
    
    if value > 1 then
        return true
    else
        return false
    end
end
  
filteredList = list.filter(filter) -- 'filteredList' contains values 2 and 3
</code>
        You can define filters in the `On Startup` file.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">filterOne( <font color="#006666">f</font> )</font>* :: `any`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*f*</font> :: `function`<br>
        The filtering function.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the first value that is approved by the given filter.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">forEach( <font color="#006666">f</font> )</font>* :: `Map`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*f*</font> :: `function`<br>
        The transformation function.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a map, where results of applying <font color="#006666">*f*</font> for each element of the list are stored under those elements(element of the list are _keys_ and the corresponding transformation results are _values_). The transformation function receives one argument and must return any value, which will be the result of the transformation.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">removeFirst( <font color="#006666">v</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that is removed.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> | `1` :: `number`<br>
        The number of removes.<br>
      * *Description*
        Removes <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> occurrences of <font color="#006666">*v*</font> starting from the back of the list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">removeLast( <font color="#006666">v</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that is removed.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> | `1` :: `number`<br>
        The number of removes.<br>
      * *Description*
        Removes <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> occurrences of <font color="#006666">*v*</font> starting from the back of the list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">replace( <font color="#006666">v</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The replacement value.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> | <font color="#006666">*size*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The number of the element.<br>
      * *Description*
        Replaces the <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font>'th value of the list with <font color="#006666">*v*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">replaceAll( <font color="#006666">v1</font> , <font color="#006666">v2</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v1*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that is replaced.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v2*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The replacement value for <font color="#006666">*v1*</font>.<br>
      * *Description*
        Replaces all occurrences of <font color="#006666">*v1*</font> with <font color="#006666">*v2*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">replaceFirst( <font color="#006666">v1</font> , <font color="#006666">v2</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v1*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that is replaced.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v2*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The replacement value for <font color="#006666">*v1*</font>.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> | `1` :: `number`<br>
        The number of replacements.<br>
      * *Description*
        Replaces <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> occurrences of <font color="#006666">*v1*</font> with <font color="#006666">*v2*</font> starting from the beginning of the list.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">replaceLast( <font color="#006666">v1</font> , <font color="#006666">v2</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    _Note: This method becomes available only after calling method <font color="#0052A3">*expand()*.</font>_<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v1*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that is replaced.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v2*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The replacement value for <font color="#006666">*v1*</font>.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> | `1` :: `number`<br>
        The number of replacements.<br>
      * *Description*
        Replaces <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> occurrences of <font color="#006666">*v1*</font> with <font color="#006666">*v2*</font> starting from the back of the list.
<br>
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted Types*<br><br>
         * `List`
         Returns `true` if the given list contains the same elements(order does not count).
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"empty"`
         Returns `true` if the current list is empty.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Map</font>====
Basically, an advanced version of the `table`. It's main advantage is that unlike the `table` it can be saved to memory. The map can be accessed either through methods: `map.put("a",1)`, `map.get("a")` or like an ordinary `table`: `map["a"] = 1`, `map["a"]`, `map.a = 1`, `map.a`. Just remember that using square brackets you cannot query values stored under string keys that are identical to method names.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Map( <font color="#5E5B00">…</font> )</font>* :: `Map`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*…*</font> :: `range` ( must not contain `nil`'s for odd elements )<br>
        A range of values of any type with an even number of elements. If the number is odd, then the last element is not counted.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a new `Map` object containing the specified key-value pairs or an empty map if the number of given values is less than 2.
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*size*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The number of elements in the map.<br>
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">clear()</font>* :: `self`<br>
    Clears the map.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">clone()</font>* :: `Map`<br>
    Returns a copy of the map.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">each()</font>* :: `function`<br>
    Returns an _iteration function_ for the current map. All you need to know about this function is that it used to go through the map using the `for` loop like so:
    <code language="lua">
for index, key, value in map.each() do
end
</code>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">keys()</font>* :: `List`<br><br>
    Returns all key values of the map.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">values()</font>* :: `List`<br><br>
    Returns all distinct values of the map.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">get( <font color="#006666">k</font> )</font>* :: `any` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*k*</font> :: `any` ( except `nil` )<br>
        The key of the map.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the value stored under the given key or `nil` if this key is empty.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">put( <font color="#006666">k</font> , <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*k*</font> :: `any` ( except `nil` )<br>
        The key of the map.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that is placed under key <font color="#006666">*k*</font>.<br>
      * *Description*
        Put the given value under the given key.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">contains( <font color="#006666">k</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*k*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The key of the map.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns `true` if the given key has a value stored under it.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">containsValue( <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value in the map.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns `true` if the given value is stored somewhere in the map.<br>
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted Types*<br><br>
         * `Map`
         Returns `true` if the given map has the same values stored under the same keys.
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"empty"`
         Returns `true` if the current map is empty.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Timer</font>====
A simple timer for counting time intervals inside the script.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Timer( <font color="#006666">t</font> )</font>* :: `Timer`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*t*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The countdown period in milliseconds.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a new `Timer` object with the given countdown period. By default, the new timer is not "turned on". If you want the timer to start "ticking" right from the moment of creation use `reset` method like so: `Timer(3000).reset()`.
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">stop()</font>* :: `self`<br>
    Clears the map.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">stopped()</font>* :: `boolean`<br>
    Returns `true` if the timer has stopped "ticking".
    * *<font color="#0052A3">reset()</font>* :: `self`<br>
    Restarts the timer.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">timeouted()</font>* :: `boolean`<br>
    Returns `true` if the timer has stopped "ticking" and restarts it. Otherwise, returns `false` and does nothing.
<br>

====<font color="#660000">Logger</font>====
An advanced version of the `TraceAI` function(the one that produces output for command */traceai*). Can output any object(even lists inside maps and so on) and data type to the specified file. A very useful tool for tracing the work of your script. This object also reacts to */traceai* command(if the `LoggerUseTraceAI` [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/GettingStarted#Settings setting] is `ON`), but only on startup: if */traceai* is turned off when the AI is being launched, then all loggers won't write anything. You would have to turn on */traceai* and restart your AI to enable loggers again.
<br>
All loggers create their files in the `Logs & Errors` folder.
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Logger( <font color="#006666">file</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">delay</font> )</font>* :: `Logger`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*file*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the file.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*delay*</font> | `0` :: `number`<br>
        Logging delay(used in method <font color="#0052A3">*log()*</font>).<br>
      * *Description*
        Creates a new `Logger`, which will write to the specified file with the specified delay.<br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Logger( <font color="#006666">file</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">delimiter</font> )</font>* :: `Logger`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*file*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the file.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*delimiter*</font> | `""` :: `string`<br>
        The string that is used as a delimiter between the values being logged(used in methods <font color="#0052A3">*log()*</font> and <font color="#0052A3">*write()*</font>).<br>
      * *Description*
        Creates a new `Logger`, which will write to the specified file using the specified string as a delimiter between the values being outputted.<br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Logger( <font color="#006666">file</font> , <font color="#006666">delay</font> , <font color="#006666">delimiter</font> )</font>* :: `Logger`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*file*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the file.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*delay*</font> :: `number`<br>
        Logging delay(used in method <font color="#0052A3">*log()*</font>).<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*delimiter*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The string that is used as a delimiter between the values being logged(used in methods <font color="#0052A3">*log()*</font> and <font color="#0052A3">*write()*</font>).<br>
      * *Description*
        Creates a new `Logger`, which will write to the specified file with the specified delay, using the specified delimiter.<br>
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">timeToLog()</font>* :: `boolean`
    Returns `true` if the delay since the last log has ended.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">resetTimer()</font>* :: `self`
    Resets the delay timer.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">log( <font color="#006666">*…*</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*…*</font> :: `range`<br>
        A range of values of any type.<br>
      * *Description*
        Writes the current timestamp("date + time" string) to the <font color="#006666">*file*</font> and(after that) textual representations of given values separating them with <font color="#006666">*delimiter*</font>. For example:
        <code language="lua">
logger = Logger("log.txt"," ")
list = List(1,2,"abc")
actor = Actor(100)
  
logger.log("an actor:",actor,"and a list:",list)
</code>
        Would output:<br><br>
        `> Week, DD Month, YYYY | HH:MM:SS > an actor: Actor[ id=100 ] and a list: `<br>
        `List[ size=3 ]:`
          `( 1 )`<br>
          `( 2 )`<br>
          `( "abc" )`<br>
        Does nothing if */traceai* is has been turned off during startup(only when `LoggerUseTraceAI` is `ON`) of AI or the delay since last log has not ended yet. 
    * *<font color="#0052A3">write( <font color="#006666">*…*</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    The same as the previous method, except it does not put a timestamp and is not affected by the delay.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">putTimestamp()</font>* :: `self`
    Writes the timestamp("date + time" string) to the <font color="#006666">*file*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">newLine()</font>* :: `self`
    "Presses the Enter key"(changes the line) in the <font color="#006666">*file*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">clear()</font>* :: `self`
    Clear the <font color="#006666">*file*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">remove()</font>* :: `self`
    Deletes the <font color="#006666">*file*</font>.
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Vector</font>====
Represents directions and positions of objects in relation to one another. Probably, the most hard-to-understand object, since it is directly related to math, but, actually, it is a very simple concept. Maps/locations in RO can be interpreted as 2D coordinate plains. No matter how you rotate your camera the plain remains the same: the direction of X-coordinate growth is the east and the Y-coordinate growth is the north. Suppose, you want to specify a direction of movement: what would you do? Well, one way of doing it is by "drawing an arrow" between 2 points. In math such arrows are called _vectors_. The "tail" of the vector will anyway be always static, so let's fix it's value to (0,0). Now we can easily define directions using only one point:
<code language="lua">
vector1 = Vector(1,0) -- Points to the east: an arrow from point (0,0) till (1,0)
  
vector2 = Vector(3,-10) -- Points to the south-east
</code>
You're probably wondering how can vectors be used? Well, RAICK allows you to manipulate them with great ease! You can take a vector and a cell and calculate a new cell, which will be `n` cells away in the direction of the vector. For example, all actors including your owner have a motion vector. If you want your homunculus to stay behind the owner at a distance of 2 cells you can write something like this: `Homun.goTo(Owner.cell - Owner.vector * 2)`. This will tell your homunculus to go to a cell that is 2 cells away from where the owner is currently standing in the opposite direction of his current movement.<br>
Another way of defining vectors is by using 2 objects/cells. The idea is the same: you are drawing an "arrow" from one object to another, except what you get is a _relational_ vector, which will define not the direction, but the position of one object in relation to another. A great example of this concept is putting traps right underneath the enemy feet:
<code language="lua">
vector = Vector(enemy, Merc) -- If the enemy is moving at us, then this vector will point in the direction of the movement
  
if Merc .. enemy <= 5 then -- If the enemy has gotten too close to the mercenary, then ..
    Merc.use(LandMine).on(enemy.cell + vector `*` 2) -- .. we put a mine between the bowman and the enemy.
end
</code>
One final thing about vectors: 2 vectors with different coordinates can point in the same direction. How is that possible? It comes from the fact that you can define vectors with different _length_. For example: (1,1.5), (2,3), (4,6) would all point in the same direction, but if you draw them on a piece of paper you would see that they have different lengths. In math the length of the vector does indeed matter, but in RAICK it has no use meaning that for RAICK they are the same(when comparing them using the `==` operator or the `is` method).
  * <u>*Constructors*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Vector( <font color="#5E5B00">x</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">y</font> )</font>* :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*x*</font> :: `number` | `0`<br>
        The X-coordinate of the vector.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*y*</font> :: `number`| `0`<br>
        The Y-coordinate of the vector.<br>
      * *Description*
        Return a new `Vector` pointing in direction specified by (<font color="#5E5B00">*x*</font>,<font color="#5E5B00">*y*</font>) coordinates. If both coordinates are not specified, then returns a _null vector_, which indicates an absence of a direction(for example, "standing" is case of a motion vector).<br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">Vector( <font color="#006666">object1</font> , <font color="#006666">object2</font> )</font>* :: `Vector` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*object1*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        The object, in relation to which the vector is calculated.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*object2*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        The object, which defines the direction of the vector in relation to <font color="#006666">*object1*</font>.<br>
      * *Description*
        Return a new `Vector` pointing in the direction specified by <font color="#006666">*object2*</font> in relation to <font color="#006666">*object1*</font>(an "arrow" drawn from <font color="#006666">*object1*</font> till <font color="#006666">*object2*</font>) or `nil` if at least one of the objects in not visible.<br>
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*x*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The X-coordinate of the vector.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*y*</font> :: `number`<br>
      The Y-coordinate of the vector.<br>
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted Types*<br><br>
         * `Vector`
         Returns `true` if the given vector is pointing in the same direction as the current one.
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"none"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector has (0,0) coordinates.
         * `"north"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to north of the current location/map.
         * `"south"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to south of the current location/map.
         * `"west"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to west of the current location/map.
         * `"east"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to east of the current location/map.
         * `"northWest"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to north-west of the current location/map.
         * `"southWest"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to south-west of the current location/map.
         * `"northEast"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to north-east of the current location/map.
         * `"southEast"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing to south-east of the current location/map.
         * `"[x];[y]"`
         Returns `true` if the current vector is pointing in the same direction as the vector with (`[x]`,`[y]`) coordinates. The delimiter ; can be replaced with anything you want as long as it is not a number, dot or minus.  For example `"-1;2"`, `"0.252|1"`.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
  * <u>*Operators*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3"><font color="#006666">cell</font> + <font color="#006666">vector</font> `*` <font color="#5E5B00">distance</font></font>* :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br>
        An arbitrary `Cell` object.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br>
        An arbitrary `Vector` object.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*distance*</font> | `1` :: `number`<br>
        The distance, by which the *<font color="#006666">cell</font>* will be shifted in the direction of *<font color="#006666">vector</font>*. Negative values will shift it in the opposite direction.<br>
      * *Description*
        This equation returns the cell, which is *<font color="#5E5B00">distance</font>* cells away from the *<font color="#006666">cell</font>* in the direction defined by *<font color="#006666">vector</font>*.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">- <font color="#006666">vector</font></font>* :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*vector*</font> :: `Cell`<br>
        An arbitrary `Vector` object.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns a new `Vector` pointing to the opposite direction of <font color="#006666">*vector*</font>.
<br>
