===<font color="#006600">Single Objects</font>===
All single objects have multiple global variables defined for them to free you from the labor of writing long names like `Mercenary` or `Homunculus`. Shorter versions start from the third letter of the type name. For example, `Owner` object has 3 variables:
   * Own
   * Owne
   * Owner
====<font color="#660000">Owner</font>====
Represents your character.<br>
Most of the fields repeat the ones that the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Actor Actor] object has, since your character is also an actor, so i won't bother describing them. The HP and SP field description is also unnecessary, since everything has been already explained in the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Points appropriate section].
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*id*</font> :: `number`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*action*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.action*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.action*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*type*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*hp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.hp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.hp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*sp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.sp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.sp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*visionRange*</font> :: `number`
      The vision range that is defined using the `VisionRange` [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/GettingStarted#Settings setting].
      * <font color="#006666">*surround*</font> :: `List`
      All actors that are currently visible on the screen(in range of vision).
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.surround*</font> :: `List`
      All actors that were visible on the screen(in range of vision) in the previous moment of time.
      * <font color="#006666">*fullSurround*</font> :: `List`
      All actors that are currently on the screen(in range of vision).
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.fullSurround*</font> :: `List`
      All actors that were on on the screen(in range of vision) in the previous moment of time.
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"full"`
         Returns `true` if your character's HP and SP are full.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
  * <u>*Operators*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3"><font color="#006666">owner</font> .. <font color="#006666">object</font></font>* :: `number` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*owner*</font> :: `Owner`<br>
        The `Owner` object.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*object*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        Any in-game object, distance till which you want to know.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the distance(in cells) between you and <font color="#006666">*object*</font> or `nil` if <font color="#006666">*object*</font> is an actor, which is not visible.
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Homunculus / Mercenary</font>====
I will unify descriptions of these objects, since they are identical.<br>
They represent your homunculus/mercenary and are both defined in the homunculus and in the mercenary scripts, since RAICK support data exchange between scripts. Read more about it in the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Data_Exchange_Between_Homunculus_and_Mercenary last section].<br>
Most of the fields repeat the ones that the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Actor Actor] object has, since your homunculus/mercenary is also an actor, so i won't bother describing them. The HP and SP field description is also unnecessary, since everything has been already explained in the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Points appropriate section].
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*id*</font> :: `number`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.cell*</font> :: `Cell`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*action*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.action*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.action*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.target*</font> :: `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*type*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.vector*</font> :: `Vector`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*hp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.hp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.hp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*sp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*prev.sp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*last.sp*</font> :: `Points`<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*hit.range*</font> :: `number`
      The range of a normal attack in cells.
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">goTo( <font color="#006666">v</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` | `Mercenary`/`Homunculus` | `Vector`<br>
        The location or the in-game character, to which the homunculus/mercenary must go or the direction(vector) of it's movement.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> :: `number`<br>
        The number of cells, by which the homunculus/mercenary must advance in the direction specified by the location, object or vector.<br>
      * *Description*
        Orders your homunculus/mercenary to go to the specified cell or to the cell, on which the specified object stand on or in the direction specified by the vector. The second argument is used to modify the length of path that the homunculus/mercenary is allowed to go through. If <font color="#006666">*v*</font> is a `Vector`, then <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> specifies the number of cells that the homunculus/mercenary should go through in the direction of the vector. In other cases:<br><br>
          * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> is a fractional value between 0 and 1
          The homunculus/mercenary will go through (<font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> `*` 100)% of the path.
          * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> is a fractional value between -1 and 0
          The homunculus/mercenary will go through ((1 + <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font>) `*` 100)% of the path.
          * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> >= 1
          The homunculus/mercenary will go through <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> cells along of the path.
          * <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> <= -1
          The homunculus/mercenary will keep <font color="#5E5B00">*n*</font> cells away from <font color="#006666">*v*</font>.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">hit( <font color="#006666">target</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*target*</font> :: `Actor`<br>
        The target.<br>
      * *Description*
        Orders your homunculus/mercenary to hit(attack with normal attacks) the specified target once.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">use( <font color="#006666">skill</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">lvl</font> )</font>* :: `self`
    * *<font color="#0052A3">use( <font color="#006666">skill</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">lvl</font> ).on( <font color="#006666">target</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*skill*</font> :: `Skill`<br>
        The skill that you want your homunculus/mercenary to use.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*lvl*</font> :: `number` | <font color="#006666">*skill.maxLevel*</font><br>
        The level of the skill.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*target*</font> :: `Actor`<br>
        The target, on which the skill should be used.<br>
      * *Description*
        The first version of this method is used for non-targeted skills and the second one is for targeted ones. If the level of the skill is omitted uses the maximum level available.
  * <u>*_is_ Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot( <font color="#006666">…</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Accepted `string` Values*<br><br>
         * `"full"`
         Returns `true` if homunculus'/mercenaries HP and SP are full.
         * `"active"`
         Returns `true` if the object is active. Explained in the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Data_Exchange_Between_Homunculus_and_Mercenary last section].
    * *<font color="#0052A3">is.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* , *<font color="#0052A3">isNot.<font color="#006666">value</font></font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
  * <u>*Operators*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3"><font color="#006666">homun/merc</font> .. <font color="#006666">object</font></font>* :: `number` | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*homun/merc*</font> :: `Homunculus`/`Mercenary`<br>
        The `Homunculus`/`Mercenary` object.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*object*</font> :: `Cell` | `Actor` | `Owner` |  `Homunculus` |  `Mercenary`<br>
        Any in-game object, distance till which you want to know.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the distance(in cells) between your homunculus/mercenary and <font color="#006666">*object*</font> or `nil` if <font color="#006666">*object*</font> is an actor, which is not visible.
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Memory</font>====
The object for manipulating the memory. Values are saved under `string` keys just like in an ordinary table. I will refer to those strings as _memory variables_ or _entries_. As an exception to the common rule: memory variables are case and delimiter <u>sensitive</u>. Read more about the memory file [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#0._Memory here].
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">save( <font color="#006666">n</font> , <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: <font color="#006666">*v*</font><br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*n*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the memory variable.<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `number` | `string` | `boolean` | `Value` | `Cell` | `Actor` | `Vector`<br>`List` ( `number` | `string` | `boolean` | `Value` | `Cell` | `Actor` | `Vector` )<br>`Map` ( `number` | `string` | `boolean` | `Value` | `Cell` | `Actor` | `Vector` )<br>
        The value that needs to be saved. The type restriction above says that only the mentioned types can be saved to the memory and if you want to save a `List` or a `Map`, then they also must contains only those types.<br>
      * *Description*
        Saves <font color="#006666">*v*</font> to memory variable <font color="#006666">*n*</font> and return <font color="#006666">*v*</font> afterwards.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">get( <font color="#006666">n</font> , <font color="#5E5B00">v</font> )</font>* :: `any` | <font color="#5E5B00">*v*</font> | `nil`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*n*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the memory variable.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*v*</font> :: `any`<br>
        The value that will be returned if <font color="#006666">*n*</font> does not exist in the memory.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns the value that is saved to <font color="#006666">*n*</font> or <font color="#5E5B00">*v*</font> if no such entry exist or `nil` if no such entry exist and <font color="#5E5B00">*v*</font> is omitted.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">contains( <font color="#006666">n</font> )</font>* :: `boolean`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*n*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the memory variable.<br>
      * *Description*
        Returns `true` if the entry <font color="#006666">*n*</font> exist in the memory.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">delete( <font color="#006666">n</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*n*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the memory variable.<br>
      * *Description*
        Deletes entry <font color="#006666">*n*</font> from the memory.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">clear()</font>* :: `self`
    Clears the memory including RAICK service data like current activity or activity arguments(the values in script variables will still be available until the restart).
<br>
----
====<font color="#660000">Activity</font>====
Through this object you can change the current activity of your homunculus/mercenary or get information about the current or the last activity. Read more about activities [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#5._Activities here].
  * <u>*Fields*</u><br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*current*</font> :: `Value`<br><br>
      Contains the name of the current activity and it's sequential number(the first activity would get 1 and so on). This value "survives" the restart of the script, since it is automatically saved to memory.
      * <font color="#006666">*last*</font> :: `Value` | `nil`<br><br>
      Contains the name of the last activity(the one that your homunculus/mercenary was before the switching to the current activity) and it's sequential number or `nil` if the AI is run for the first time and there is historical data available.
  * <u>*Methods*</u><br><br>
    * *<font color="#0052A3">switchTo.<font color="#006666">activity</font>( <font color="#5E5B00">…</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*activity*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The name of the activity.<br>
        * <font color="#5E5B00">*…*</font> :: `range` ( `number` | `string` | `boolean` | `Value` | `Cell` | `Actor` |  `Points` |  `Skill` | `Vector` )<br>
        A range of values with arbitrary number of elements.<br>
      * *Description*
        Switches your homunculus/mercenary to <font color="#006666">*activity*</font> activity with given arguments. Two <font color="#006666">*activity*</font> names have special meaning:<br><br>
          * `initial`
          Switches to the first state that is defined in the `Activities` file.
          * `last`
          Switches to the <font color="#006666">*last*</font> activity or does nothing if it is `nil`.
        As always, <font color="#006666">*activity*</font> is case and delimiter insensitive.
    * *<font color="#0052A3">changeArgument( <font color="#006666">n</font> , <font color="#006666">v</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
      * *Arguments*<br><br>
        * <font color="#006666">*n*</font> :: `string`<br>
        The sequential number of the argument(starting from 1).<br>
        * <font color="#006666">*v*</font> :: `number` | `string` | `boolean` | `Value` | `Cell` | `Actor` |  `Points` |  `Skill` | `Vector`<br>
        The new value of the argument.<br>
      * *Description*
        Changes the <font color="#006666">*n*</font>'th argument of the current activity to <font color="#006666">*v*</font>.
<br>
----
==<font color="#006666">Detailed Overview of Files</font>==
Partially this topic is covered in the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/GettingStarted#AI_Specific_Files Getting Started] chapter. I will just introduce the facts that'll complete the picture.<br>
All of RAICK's AI files share one common feature, which simplifies and quickens the scripting process. The idea is quite simple: global variables with _special_ names are translated into strings. What this means is that, for example, if you are querying a global variable `visible`(and this variable contains `nil`- it has not been used or has been cleared after usage), then the result of the query will be string `"visible"`. So, how do you know which names are _special_? Here is the list:
  * Status names(<font color="#006666">*status*</font> field)
  * Group names(<font color="#006666">*group*</font> field)
  * Type names(<font color="#006666">*type*</font> field) ›› _! Every monster !_
Like everywhere in RAICK the names are case and delimiter insensitive meaning that, for example, `ma__Ya__--Pu__rple` is the same as `MayaPurple`. This also concerns the names of handler functions and activities discussed below. For example: `a_l_t_shift_TARGET` and `AltShiftTarget` refer to the same handler function.
===<font color="#006600">0. Memory</font>===
The memory file is automatically created and managed by RAICK. This is where your saved values are stored. If you open it, you will first of all see a header saying when the memory was last updated and how many percent of it's capacity is currently taken. The header is followed by the list of entries, each of them with it's own small header, which specifies the type of the value, as well as the number of elements if the value is a `List` or a `Map`. Values between underscores like `_s_` are RAICK service memory entries- they should not be altered.
<br>
The file itself can be manually altered, but if you make any mistakes you won't be able to run your AI properly until you either fix the error or delete the memory file.
<br>
----
===<font color="#006600">1. On Startup</font>===
The content of this file is run only once, when your AI is being loaded. This is the only file that is not pre-processed meaning that everything you define here will be visible in all parts of your script exactly the way it is defined. Typically, you will use this file to put initial values to your variables or to define your own custom functions.
<br>
----
===<font color="#006600">2. Commands</font>===
The file, where you define _handler_ functions that intercept `Ctrl + Something` or `Alt + Something` commands. Upon creation it is automatically filled with all available command handlers. The usage is straightforward: the name refers to the key combination and the arguments are either the cell or the target actor that you click on.<br>
Anything other than the handler functions will be ignored.
<br>
----
===<font color="#006600">3. Skills</font>===
The file, where you define _handler_ functions that intercept commands to use a targeted skill. Upon creation it is also automatically filled with all available skill handlers. The second argument is always the skill level used and the first one is either a cell or an actor depending of the type of the skill: ground- or enemy-targeted.<br>
Anything other than the handler functions will be ignored.
<br>
----
===<font color="#006600">4. Messages</font>===
The file, where you define _handler_ functions that intercept messages sent from one AI script to another. This allows your bots to communicate with each other. You can read more about this wonderful feature in the [http://code.google.com/p/raick/wiki/Manual#Data_Exchange_Between_Homunculus_and_Mercenary last section]
<br>
----
===<font color="#006600">5. Activities</font>===
The final and the most important file is the one, where you define your activities. The first activity that you define is called _initial_. When you run your script for the first time RAICK does not know what is the current activity(since the memory is empty), so it uses the first activity as the current one.<br>
Two activity names are _special_: `pre` and `post`(plus all case and delimiter insensitive variations). The first one is called every time before the current activity function is called and the second one is called after the current activity executes. Typically, you would use those to define periodical events like casting self-support skills.<br>
There is also one hidden activity, to which your bot is switched if RAICK encounters an error in your script. It this activity your bot will follow you and you will have an ability to manually use it's skills. You can think of it as a _Safe Mode_.<br>
Activities can take arguments, which are automatically saved to the memory.
<br>
----
==<font color="#006666">Understanding RAICK Errors</font>==
Whenever RAICK encounters an error inside your script or inside the framework itself it generates a descriptive report about the type and the cause of the error. This report is then showed to the user in the error window and documented to the `Logs & Errors/Error Logs.txt` file or to the `RAICK.Bugz.txt` file in case the error came from RAICK. Finally, your bot is switched to the _Safe Mode_ to cut-off the possibility of the error occurring again.<br>
The error report may contain following rows:
  * `[!] ERROR TYPE [!]`
  The type of the error. Can be:
    * `ERROR IN SETTINGS`
    You have made an error in `RAICK.Settings.lua` file.
    * `SYNTAX ERROR`
    You have made a syntactical error somewhere in your script.
    * `INVALID ARGUMENT ERROR`
    An invalid argument has been given to a function.
    * `MEMORY OVERFLOW ERROR`
    You have exceeded the capacity of the memory.
    * `LUA ERROR`
    A typical Lua error that RAICK is unable to classify.
  * `File`
  The file, where the error has occurred.
  * `Line`
  The line of the file, on which the error occurred.
  * `Cause`
  Why the error occurred.
  * `Function`/`Operator`
  The name of the function, method or operator, which was used incorrectly.
  * `Argument`
  The sequential number(or place relative to the operator: left, right) of the invalid argument.
  * `Expected`
  The correct type or value of the argument.
  * `Got`
  The received/incorrect type or value of the argument.
  * `Solution`
  What RAICK will do or has done to fix the problem.
  * `[!] ATTENTION [!]` footer
  If you see a footer starting with this row, then the error is the bug of the framework, not your script. You should report about it as soon as possible.
<br>
----
==<font color="#006666">Data Exchange Between Homunculus and Mercenary</font>==
A truly unique feature of RAICK is the ability to unify two scripts in one making bot communication painless and a joy to use.<br>
So, here's how it works. First of all, you have to turn `ON` the `BotCommunication` setting and restart both of your scripts(_Character Select_ is the best way to do it, since mercenaries cannot be _Rest_'ed). The `Homunculus` object in the mercenary AI and the `Mercenary` object in the homunculus AI will now "come to life". They will fully replicate the "original" objects(all fields + all methods) from the corresponding/opposite AI's as long as the second bot(i call it _cobot_) is in range of vision. The fact that the cobot is in your sight can be checked through the `is` method: `is.active` returns `true` if the cobot is in range of sight. When the object is inactive the methods will not function and it won't contain any data.<br>
Just think about it! Basically, you can use only one AI to control both of your bots! And there is even something extra! Besides having total control over the actions and the data of the cobot you can also send messages to it using the following method, which appears inside the bot object(the original object inside it's AI) if the communication is turned `ON`:
  * *<font color="#0052A3">send.<font color="#006666">message</font>( <font color="#006666">value</font> )</font>* :: `self`<br><br>
    * *Arguments*<br><br>
      * <font color="#006666">*message*</font> :: `string`<br>
      The name of the message.<br>
      * <font color="#006666">*value*</font> :: `number` | `string` | `boolean` | `Value` | `Cell` | `Actor` |  `Points` |  `Skill` | `Vector`<br>
      The value that you want to send.<br>
    * *Description*
      Calls the <font color="#006666">*message*</font> handler function defined in the `Messages` file of the cobot's AI passing the <font color="#006666">*value*</font> to it. If the handler function with this name(plus all case and delimiter insensitive variations) is not defined, then nothing happens. During a single execution of the activity(call of the AI by the client) only one value can be sent using this method.
Using this method you can send values of specified data types to the opposite side. The second AI will receive them through handler functions defined in the `Messages` file. Every such function must be defined with one argument to be able to receive those values. For example:
<code language="lua">
-- Somewhere in the Homunculus AI:
Homun.send.killHim(actor)
...
-- In the Messages file of the Mercenary AI:
function    KILL_HIM(enemy)
    
    mainTarget = Memory.save("mainTarget", enemy)
    Activity.switchTo.terminationOf(mainTarget)
end
</code>
